By the time they came to get my group's order, it was 7:20 and they wouldn't let us order from that menu because it's only served until 7!! In my defense, we should have been able to order from that menu, especially because they gave us that menu (so what that the "specials" menu had a second side we could order from...it wasn't any good). One of my friend, like me, really wanted to order from that menu while the rest of our group wanted us to just give in (who does that...I'm ready to put up a fight any day, well ok not a real fight but I don't like to give up without trying).

So fine, I settled for just some Panaang curry with chicken and it was delicious! My culture doesn't eat spicy food 24/7 so my food was killing me softly the more I ate of it. 

They had a large selection and I feel in love with their Thai Tea. I still dream of it to this day.
author: Polina W.

description:
I ordered a combo special meal $10.95 and added a bowl of soup for an extra $2.50

the service was great and they were very attentive and friendly & fast,  I thought my meal was well prepared the chicken meat used was breast meat in my Pra Ram [chicken with peanut sauce & veggies] the coconut soup also had white meat chicken, this must be the new trend in Thai restaurants? for some reason they never serve dark meat? I wish Thai restaurants would use dark meat and white meat and leave the skin on it, I think it tastes better that way. The meal also came with Pad Thai & fried rice and a couple shrimp rolls with sweet dipping sauce

the coconut soup had a good flavor and complimented my meal well

overall I still thought this was a nice restaurant and would come back again, it's well kept and the restrooms were also kept clean

I usually start with a combo plate when it's my first time dining at a new restaurant that Ive never been to before, after seeing other dishes other customers were ordering I'll probably try something different next time

prices didnt seem too high and were very reasonable IMO
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
As someone that has been in Thailand and someone that has family that has lived in Thailand for a long period of time, I feel the Old Siam was pretty on-point when it came to Thai food. I got the regular Pad Thai with chicken and it was scrumptious. I scarfed it down basically in an instant, which is saying something because the serving was pretty generous, and all for decent prices. Of course, I was staying at the Hilton Union Square right next door where eggs delivered to the room cost $28. Anything could be considered cheap compared to that.

The Pad Thai was not as spicy as what one would get in Thailand, but that is easily fixed by ladling on any of the three spicy toppings the Old Siam has in glasses on the table. I was pretty ecstatic to see they served Chang and Leo beers, both of which I loved while over in Thailand. While I'm on the topic, if ever you get the chance to get your hands on a Beer Lao, don't hesitate! One of my favorite beers while over in Thailand and one that will definitely bring out your inner Communist! But I digress...

I also ordered the banana roti and it was very well done. It could have been the exact same as one ordered at a street cart in Bangkok. Our server was friendly and helpful and even spoke some Thai, which is a welcome sight to someone accustomed to non-Asians working in Asian restaurants in the U.S.

By the way: service was extremely fast, and it's pretty close to the most whimsical place in San Francisco... Tenderloin! How can you go wrong?
author: Zach P.

description:
I've been here a number of times now and have to say it's consistently friendly, reasonably priced and the food is usually spot on.

The atmosphere is casual/comfortable, kind of spacious, and while they do a decent business, I've never had to wait for a table.

Definitely the kind of place you can always count on for a decent, quick meal, before or after a movie, in the midst of some shopping, or for last minute dinner plans.
author: Edward H.

description: This place was recomended by a staff member at the hotel I was staying at. Walked a few blocks and was exactly what the guy was talking about. Reminds me of an old latenight dinner except they have Thai/fusion food. No fluffs. Not fancy by any means but the food was exceptional. Everything we ate was excellent. If you want good quality thai food, this is the place. If you are looking for a candle light dinner, this may not be for you. Coming back again the next time visiting SF.
author: Anil S.

description: While visiting San Francisco I found this place just because it was near the hotel.  Very small place, service is quick. I ordered the Thai fried rice and the #79 on their menu, which is a crispy strip chicken  with onions, peppers and cashews. ....really really good. I ordered it 3 nights in a row. The portions are very generous as well. They also have a homemade lemonade that's really good.
author: C A.

description: Food was OK, but the service was excruciatingly slow. Even with plenty of servers and a normal size lunch crowd.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Ku tiew (beef noodle soup) #30 was just like mama makes it. So much flavor in the broth.  The Som Tum (papaya salad) was also magnificent - ask for Thai taste if you want authentic. Prices were good. Will be back to try more
author: Tammy L.

description:
I love this place!! 

Been here many times for lunch because it's close to where I work (and the food is delicious and such a bargain!)  One of my favorites is "kao soy" -- noodles in curry sauce with chicken, pickled veggies, and red onions--a rare menu item from northern Thailand) that you don't find in many Thai restaurants.
author: Nicha K.

description: Great curry and a good location to Union Square.  The fried tofu app was delicious and enough for 2-3 people.
author: Tori L.

description:
This is my favorite place for Duck Soup! The broth is light and flavorful. The duck is carefully sliced up to always include a little fat with the tasty meat. The tender bok choy has a slight crunch and sets off the duck flavor perfectly.  You can get the soup with any asian style noodle you want. I always choose the thin rice noodle as it it easy to manage. 
I have had a few other dishes here...but why? Get the Duck Soup!!!
author: Mark B.

description:
This was the first disappointing experience we had in San Francisco.  We stopped in here on a lark after getting some shopping done at Powell BART, but this was a pretty gross in general.

We ordered the green onion pancake, thinking it might be similar to the chinese/taiwanese green onion pancake.  I'm not sure if it's supposed to be, but what we got was a very thick undercooked dough, covered in salt and MSG.  I don't remember if I started developing a headache immediately, but it was the kind of headache that I can remember a month after eating.

We ordered our typical Thai dishes when we're not sure about the specialties of the place -- Pad See Ew and Panang Curry -- which were both edible, and despite being incredibly salty, pretty bland and flavorless otherwise.

We ended up having to take most of our dishes home -- which we ate begrudgingly chanting "don't waste food" over and over, while drinking gallons of water trying to stave off the MSG headache.

I will give the place credit for being open close to Powell late at night, and for being clean and edible.  Unfortunately, there's not much to recommend after that.
author: Jeff Y.

description: No. Sorry, the food was not good and definitely not authentic.  First of all they had Chinese food dishes on their menu.  We had the trout with sweet and sour sauce, which was way too sweet,  mango chicken and prawn curry - there were two pieces of small shrimp and not really a curry taste, and the spicy noodle with ground pork, which was just average.  Service was also average.  With so many other Thai food options around, I will definitely not be back.
author: Sylvia W.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant in the entire world. It has ruined eating at other places for me. The tea is great, the rice has a flavor I've found nowhere else, the service is great, and I've never had a bad dish here. All your Thai favorites can be found
author: Robert V.

description:
Seated right away at 7. Service was on top of it. Ordered pumpkin curry. It turned out to be everything I dreamed of in a curry. So much to choose from on the menu, great prices, I'll will be back! 

No complaints at all.
author: Tina T.

description: Delicious Thai food. Got the express lunch which comes with an app, pad thai, and choice of entree for 11.95. The pad thai and fried tofu was bland but the yellow curry I picked for my entree was delicious.
author: Sarah L.

description: the service at this place was very good and fast. along with a friendly staff and fast service they had good prices for alcohol but the food wasn't the best thai i've had.  i would come again if i was low on money.
author: Cecilia L.

description:
In the heart of the one and only TL, but who cares this place is delish!

Parking might be a bitch, all the crackheads down the street might scare you a bit lol but despite all that every dish I've tried here has been SO GOOD. Service is good, and not much to complain about!!!
author: Rosh E.

description:
slow service for lunch and super questionable pad thai in the lunch special (super thick, round noodles for some reason with a pinkish color and very little flavor). i ordered the pumpkin curry which was good, but not fantastic.

even if you're sharing, order the rice plate and not a la carte since they're basically the same size anyway.
author: Cailin H.

description: My friend and I went here on 2-3-15 Tuesday 8:10pm'sh.  I decided to order fried rice with chicken, beef, squid, onion and thai ice tea, my friend ordered a flat noodle soup with ice tea.  I was surprised the food is good and enjoyed the thai ice tea---note that fortunately there is a good chef cooking during that time.  Prices are moderately expensive but expected due to the size of this restaurant. Service is attentive.
author: Jer W.

description: I always make the trip to Union Square just to eat here.(No shopping for me!). I go through the menu and always end up getting the same thing - Tofu Himapan. Delicious. Enough Said.
author: Ravi T.

description: This place is truly a hidden gem in the tourist district. The garlic fish - fried - was really yummy. And the price is right. We were stuffed - two of us - for $20. Perfect to take your friend who's staying in the financial district, who's jetlagged, on a rainy night for a quick dinner.
author: Andrew K.

description: The food is cheap and very tasty! I always look for larb gai at every Thai restaurant I go to, and I was so pleased they make excellent larb gai for less than $8. The beef salad is also stellar. If you get a side of steamed vegetables for $4 they give you plenty for 2 people which is great too!
author: Lauren T.

description:
Tasty Thai food in a (busy) "no frills" restaurant.
We had dinner with a group of 15; usually with a group it's hard to all eat at the same time.
Not at Old Siam; we ordered different dishes and dined family style.  

It didn't take longer than 10 minutes before we had our (12!!!) different dishes ob the table.
Staff is fast and friendly.

We had dishes as egg rolls, green curry, duck, beef and broccoli, different kinds of fried rice, trout with spice sauce, catfish and green beans. 
It all tasted delicious. 

Definitely a good choice.
author: Ellen G.

description:
Price- 5 stars
Taste- 10 stars
Service- 5 stars
Friendliness- 5 stars
Environment- 5 stars

Hands down my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  I'm so glad I happened upon this gem of a place.  I go there as often as I can.  This place has given me some of the best meals I've had in my life.  For me, this is heaven.  Almost too good to be true.  And the prices are amazing.  Just go there.
author: Ellary R.

description: Great pad thai, great bbq pork... Service slow but overall still good for the price considering its in the middle of the city.
author: Abby C.

description: Every now and then, I'm in the mood to have some Thai food. This is the perfect place to go; if you're shopping downtown or simply going on a date. I recommend trying the lunch special during weekdays...deliciousness!
author: Gustavo C.

description:
We were going to Infusion Lounge and happened to find this delicious Thai place right across the street. We went at 9 p.m. and were happy to find that they were still open. The bright neon sign made us think that it was going to be pretty cheesy, but we were pleasantly surprised.

Ordered the Duck Basil ($9.95) and the Pad Thai ($7.95). The Duck Basil was really flavorful and came with rice. The Pad Thai was really tasty too, I wish it had been a little spicier though. Their beers (including the Chang and Singha bottles) were all $3.95 each. Most of the staff was also Thai : )
author: Julie C.

description:
Best Thai food I've ever had - they set the bar very high for me!  Tried several of their dishes, and my favorites were:

1. siam curry delight - red curry with mango, prawns, scallops, and asparagus - my favorite!
2. mango curry - very tasty and not too spicy
3. garlic prawns - deliciously spicy (a bit salty)
4. sweet chicken - nice contrast with the spicy chile

Their mango dishes are incredible!  The staff are very friendly, attentive, and courteous.  They usually have a nearly full restaurant, but they managed to seat me quickly.  The portions are generous, so you won't go away hungry.  

Tip: If there's a wait, take the opportunity to watch the pictures of the entrees scrolling on the two tv's.  They all look so delicious, it's hard to make a decision.
author: Rick A.

description: The duck noodle soup was really really good. The broth was so tasty. The only thing is that half of the rice noodles are in tiny pieces, probably a little overcooked. Would recommend to friends.
author: Chiao-Yu T.

description: I decided to come here one day for lunch since I always pass by it walking to and from my internship. They were pretty busy with a lot of two tops. Looking at their menu, I decided to go with their Lunch combo for $10.95! I got Fried tofu appetizer with Lemon grass chicken entree. It was GOOD! The lemon grass chicken (my favorite) was not dry at all and it was bursting with flavor! Just enough food for a decent price. The service was excellent letting me know which items had dairy in it and offering to make substitutions for my allergies. I think I just found a new lunch spot in the city! :)
author: Marissa C.

description:
I don't know whether they're still together, but I would love to see Haircut One Hundred in concert.  Really.  Truly.  I'm not making this stuff up.  I'm not even telling you this solely because I don't know a cleverer way to intro my Old Siam Thai Restaurant review, although I would be lying if I said that that didn't play any part in my decision.

I mean, seriously, who wouldn't want to see these gangly British guys performing hits like "Favourite Shirts (Boy Meets Girl)" and "Love Plus One"?  Except that they're not in their twenties anymore, so they're probably not gangly, and even if they are thin in that rare way that a 58-year-old David Byrne can be, they wouldn't look particularly thin, which would ruin some of the magic, I think.  But then you'd hear that weird horn bridge part of L+1, and you'd be magically transported to your childhood, and the strangeness of sonic memory-feeling connections would get stuck in your mind, and assuming you didn't ingest too many controlled or uncontrolled substances, this experience would probably stick with you for a while.  Haircut One Hundred.  In 2011.

I'm always suspicious of places that list non-vegetarian-looking ingredients in the descriptions of their offerings in the vegetarian section.  It's a different animal when it's an all-vegetarian restaurant.  Then, I assume that the chicken isn't really chicken and the beef isn't really beef.  But at a normal Thai restaurant--scratch that--a less-then-normal-for-San Francisco Thai restaurant?  Please.  Oyster sauce can be made from mushrooms, I believe, and this vegetarian version might actually be cheaper than the real animal (gotcha!), so I have no doubt that Old Siam Thai Restaurant uses non-oyster-derived oyster sauce.  But what if it doesn't?  Well, my friends, it might deserve a

GRATUITOUS-MEAT ALERT

Listen, Ed U.  I understand and appreciate most of what you're about.  I've clicked so many clicks that I don't feel the need to explain myself; but I really should have visited Thai Dishes with my father, brother, and nephew; and I kind of blame you, sort of.

The '80s interior is pretty spectacular.  I love that it was clearly done recently.  It feels like some strange Asian-influenced airport lounge straight out of my childhood imagination on the ride home from my great-aunt's house after she and my great-uncle had returned from a trip to Singapore, which they called the Orient.

The food is all right.  It's nowhere near as good as I expected it to be, but I really don't know why I was expecting so much.

Back to Haircut One Hundred.  True two-hit wonders are the rarest of breeds.  And although there is a slew of bands that name their songs irreferentially (think New Order), how many true two-hit wonders can you say the same of?

Oh, the servers wear special shirts.  Perhaps not favourite shirts, but special shirts nonetheless.
author: John S.

description:
Came here on a Friday night before an improv show nearby -- we were in a rush + there was no wait, and the menu had pumpkin curry. 

I love pumpkin curry and it was good here too, but given the atmosphere (which was whatever) and the prices (not super cheap given that it looks like a cheap place) I would probably not come back. 

One thing that annoyed me was the fact that the entrees that came with rice were cheaper than ordering a la carte, as opposed to the other way around. It doesn't matter too much in the end, esp. if you plan on sharing, but kind of confused me as far as menus go.
author: Richa A.

description:
The service is really good for Thai standards and 2 dishes are more than enough for 2 people. 

The flavors and portion sizes make this place an excellent value.  I noticed that no shortcuts on flavors are taken here.  No substitutes to speed things which brings the food to another level.

After finishing our meal we discussed our next meal here and how it might become our new regular spot.
author: Roger H.

description: The best squid salad I ever had ! My husband choose a mango curry and it was a blast too. We went on a Saturday night and it was crowded, and the service not really good ... But the food amazed us !
author: Celine D.

description: Try the pad thai!  Excellent!  On a corner and the seating is a bit tight.  Service is good, with a casual atmosphere, and close to the Hotel Nikko so it was convenient.  We went here twice and were not disappointed as the food and service were certainly consistent.  The interior could use a little updating, however.
author: Brooke K.

description: Clean environment, yummy food, reasonable price, that's all I'm looking for as a tourist. 4 star, recommended.
author: Kris W.

description: never crowded and they have great thai food.  I like their Pad Kra Prow (minced chicken with basil).  I usually have at least one meal here when I am in the city for work.
author: Joel M.

description:
This is definitely not a welcoming place! The staff at this place is extremely discourteous and inconsiderate! Just today, two of their waitresses did not allow me to stay inside for a few minutes after I had finished my dinner, as I intended to wait for the rain to stop and for my bus to arrive--the restaurant is right in front of a bus stop I frequently use. Very insensitive and frustrated staff, indeed! They even refused to give me their manager's name as they were basically kicking me out of there! They told me they just had to close and that I have to understand they got a life too (whatever that means to them), but I believe they just don't get rewarded at their workplace for providing quality customer service!

This place is for tourists, as is surrounded by four five-star hotels, the reason why this business is a success. Customer service lacks good, professional, Western style mannerism approach, but service is definitely not slow. Their food could get my B rating. Their pricing is fair. Their red rice (which they called "brown rice") is a good option.

But the atmosphere is not classy, elegant, or cozy. THIS PLACE IS FREEZING, EVEN IN THE SUMMER. Obviously, they don't care about classiness or elegance. The waiters are always running back and forth frantically and their service totally lacks consideration to the customer!

By the way, THERE'S NO TV in this place, contrary to what's stipulated on Yelp!
author: Raymond F.

description:
I always wanted to try this place and I did yesterday.  The food was excellent, the service very good and I was very surprised how clean it was.  

I will continue to eat here.
author: Kenneth G.

description:
I stopped here randomly one night after a long day of biking around the city. Maybe it was just the hunger talking or maybe it was my inexperience with Thai food, but I was really happy with the food, despite what other Yelpers have been saying. I have to admit, I gobbled it all down. I had a seafood dish with a lemon basil sauce and my boyfriend had the pad thai. Awesome.

What wasn't awesome was the service. I literally had to stare down the waitress from across the room before she came over to get our order. And when we first walked in it was chaotic, like no one knew how to deal with the people walking through the front doors. Then we ordered and it took probably 10 minutes to get our drinks. 

The girls working all looked busy. I did not notice any of them just hanging out and chatting, but all the same, there seemed to be a serious lack of staff organization. 

I'd probably go back if I was in the area and not in a rush to be served, but I wasn't exactly wowed by the place.
author: Lauren L.

description: I worked a block away from here and decided to grab dinner here with my coworkers. services was fast. food came out in a timely manner. place was clean and price was reasonable. They have curry mango ! I had never tried that and i love fruits in my entrees. it was okay, a bit spicy but then again my tolerance for spiciness is really low. I also liked their garlic tofu dish. I came for take out during lunch hour - it can be really busy so the wait was a little longer. oh all glide staff members get a discount :) that's always nice.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Favorite Thai Restaurant in San Francisco!
Affordable, tasty, close to Nob Hill, close to Public Transportation & BART.

After eating the best curry I've had in my life in Bangkok, Thailand, this comes in a close second!

During my last week in San Francisco, I ate here 3 times, and must have eaten here 15+ times within a span of six months.

I'm not usually a fan of combos, but it definitely works here!

I usually get the combo that gets the: 
Red Beef Curry, Pad Thai, Egg rolls, and then I ask for the Thai Iced Tea. 
For desert: Mango sticky rice!

When I think of Best Thai in the United States, I think of this place.
author: Erin M.

description:
Totally decent Thai at reasonable prices.  The pad thai and green curry were both standard-issue and tasty, and the mango with sticky rice was heavenly.

Probably the best Thai in the neighborhood.
author: Dana S.

description:
My place for Thai food during my break from work. I love their fried chicken over fried rice; so deliciously breaded and crispy, omg. I used to get Thai from another place close to my workplace as well, but when one of my co-workers recommended it, I fell in love. SO much better than the old Thai place I used to go to; I don't even go there anymore, even if they give me discount because the 10% off is not even worth it anymore.
The staff is friendly (service with a smile; always), food is always served quickly and you can order for pick up. It's a small place, but don't be deceived because it's totally worth it.
author: Michelley D.

description:
Nothing bad to say about this delicious place, though i have only ordered take out, never sat down to experience their service.

Pumpkin Curry Duck and Beef Drunken Noodle are my 2 favorite items.  You get alot of food and its not pricey.
author: Todd S.

description: Loved the veg rolls wrapped in rice paper. The Tofu Himapan I ordered was super greasy.  Other than that - great location, quick service
author: Ruchika I.

description: Came here on New Years eve around 10:30pm without a reservation and we were positive that we were going to be turned away. Not only did they accommodate us, but dished out a delicious fare. The friends we were with grew up in Thailand and cook Thai food at home every day, so they definitely know their stuff when it comes to Thai food and it met with their approval as well. We had the Khao Suey, Yum Woon Sen (glass noodles), Fried Mee Krob and Pad Kra Pao (Basil chicken) and all of them were fantastic. All the food in general is spicy, so don't tell the waitress that you want extra spicy, you will regret! Would definitely recommend...
author: Priyanka P.

description:
More modern decor than was expected from the exterior, but I was sat by the busser station, which is right in the middle of the restaurant, and there was an absolutely awful smell coming from the stack of unwashed dishes stacked there. 

I got the lunch combo, which was a lot of food for $10: 2 golden bags, side of veg pad Thai, rice, and basil chicken. The basil chicken was recommended by my server from the available options, but I didn't really care for it: greasy and the basil was overwhelming. The golden bags were actually probably the only thing on the plate I would eat again: thin, crispy wonton wrapper with a somosa-like vegetable filling inside.

The food took a very long time to come out, even though it was after prime lunch hours, but the servers were very nice. I'm betting they have some better menu options than the things I tried, but if you go, just make sure they seat you either at the very front or very back of the place!
author: Sarah F.

description: Awesome, authentic and affordable....doesn't look like much from the outside but definitively go..m.
author: Concerned C.

description:
If you want some pushy waitress expecting a tip after a meal that you barely ate. This is the place for you. 

On May 14, 2011 I've experienced a really bad meal. I've had better experiences. If anything, a near by Thai place that I've had better experiences was the House of Thai, WHICH IS MUCH BETTER!

After initially giving "them" NOTING and I mean "them" because the lady who was pushy expecting a tip was a different lady than the lady who was actually serving me. So, I gave them a $2 reluctant tip. 

This lady who came off really pushy literally gave me back the receipt and the cash that I gave to them saying this doesn't include tip. WELL DUH! You call this service? You call this quality Thai food! B.S. This lady had short hair and quite pushy, rude, and if anything probably felt entitled to better hospitality. Look lady... if you want a tip perhaps you can have better hospitality and the quality of the food needs a MAJOR upgrade. 

Thank you but I hope you get fired, already.
author: Ronnel C.

description: Good for dinner combinations where you get to try appetizer, rice, noodles and courseB all for $10.  Food is not that great.  I wouldn't recommend this place if its your first time to try Thai food or if you are bringing guests.  Even the Thai resto at Westfield mall food court would beat the flavor that Old Siam lacks.
author: Hema K.

description: Bottom line...just go! Fresh dishes, great prices, and nice service! Don't go crazy researching where to get some great Thai in SF...just go here! Delish!
author: Carlos G.

description:
I only got take-out, so I'll comment accordingly.

The service was fast and polite.  It was close to my hotel, reasonably-priced, and when I'm traveling convenience counts

The green curry has great flavor, but the curry sauce was thinner to which I am accustomed. The vegetables were fresh and crunchy. 

Bonus points for the cheeky "We reserve the right to refuse service to anyone" sign rigth inside the front door.

I'd eat here again, so that makes for an overall '3'.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Whenever we go to the city, for some reason, we always crave Thai food.  And when we think of Thai, we want "King of Thai".  However, due to time constraints, we opted for the Old Siam Thai Restaurant.  And good thing we did.  

The way I measure good ass Thai food is by their Pad Thai and Pad See Ew, and of course Thai Iced Tea.  Portions were perfect, not too much, not too little.  Had their Green Curry and Crispy Chicken over rice.  But their mango w/sticky rice and fried banana with ice cream, yummy!  Overall, good Thai food!
author: Antoinette T.

description:
Old Siam is A-OK. For being in the center of downtown where everything is a little more expensive, the lunch special is a good value - coming in at under $10 for curry and Pad Thai and a couple of accompaniments.

The red curry is very good but I wish the Pad Thai had been a little more than noodles and included some of the usual additional ingredients like tofu, bean sprouts, etc. 

Like I said, good value and if you find yourself nearby, by all means stop.
author: J T.

description: To be honest, we were actually on our way to try a Pakistani restaurant, but we were so hungry we stopped here.  We ordered the fried tofu to start to hold us till our dinner came!  Yum.  I ordered the Thai Pad Se-ew, which I tend to almost always order when I go to any Thai restaurants.  It's my favorite.  I was so hungry I couldn't wait to try this dish here.  To be honest, it tasted kind of plain.  Like an ingredient was missing.  Maybe they forgot something?  I was so hungry (do you get how hungry I was?) I didn't complain.  I still gave this place 4 stars because my honey's dish was excellent (he ordered  some type of fish) and the service was good too.  Maybe just an off night on the Thai Pad Se-ew...??
author: Stefanie S.

description: I had the chicken pad thai and the fresh rolls. I almost always get pad thai and this compared nicely to other Thai restaurants that I have been to. It did set a bit on my way back to the office so it was a little hard to pick apart the noodles, but other than that it was good. The fresh rolls were really good and had a great dipping sauce. I would definitely go back again.
author: Heather S.

description: Two weeks ago, I was in San Francisco to attend a conference. I stayed at Park 55. this restaurant was just across the street Mason. One evening my friends (all 4) ate at this restaurant. We ordered 5 dishes and shared them together. Each  dish was delicious and unique. All different flavors. In particular, I liked noodle soup. I used to enjoy Thai noodle soups. but this one really stood out. Our bill was just $70 with tips. affordable dishes in SF. Every body really enjoyed the dinner. Service was little in a hurry mode. Many were waiting inside the restaurant. Other than that, everything was wonderful.
author: Sung C.

description: I was in town for a conference and am delighted that I stopped in!  The food was fantastic! I had the Tom Kha Gai and the Masaman Curry, the best I have ever had. Don't think twice, if you like Thai, you have to try this restaurant!
author: Joshua H.

description:
Why is it when you're not hungry, it seems as though there are too many restaurants; and when you're starving, you can't find a single place to eat? 

Walking through the streets of the city, I was in search of something, ANYTHING to eat. I stumbled upon The Old Siam Thai Restaurant and checked out their menu displayed outside. The dishes and prices looked great, so I grabbed a seat inside and immediately ordered veggie egg rolls. Served piping hot with a sweet and sour sauce, I devoured those in a few minutes. 

I wasn't sure if I was in the mood for green or yellow curry, so I asked the sweet server if I could try each. She said yes, but after a few minutes, a new server came to me and asked if I was ready to order. I made my request again and he said that each dish was made to order, so the sauces weren't made. Hmmm. Believable, but now that I'm writing this, doesn't sound too true. Regardless, he was kind and I ordered--sorry, I can't remember the name--some dish with yellow curry sauce, chicken, potatoes and onions with a serving of white rice. Too bad I was full, so I only enjoyed a few bites of this. 

The food wasn't hot--at all--so I had to add a lot of red sauce, which wasn't too hot either. But I have a high tolerance for spice, so I can't fault them for that. I'd recommend this place to any Thai fans.
author: Farrah A.

description: Went for lunch, place was busy but we got our food and ate in under an hour. The panang curry was awesome, as was the "fresh coconut juice" - although the waiter told me it came from a can, so the menu is rather misleading (depending on your definition of fresh). But the panang curry was awesome.
author: K M.

description: We ate here twice during our week long stay. It was very delicious. Stick with the curries. My favorite was the green chicken curry. The Thai iced coffee was to die for. Great prices. Good quality food. Fast!
author: A L.

description: Awesome food! If you ever visit San Francisco you need to eat here. Service was great and fast.
author: Daphne I.

description: Food was ok, but the service was not. The server gave us a snooty remark after asking to split the check in 2... Returns and waits for me to sign and put the total. I  decided not to give a tip. So she tells me "no tip?, no tip?" I grab my bags to walk away, then she tells her coworkers (in a non quiet voice) no tip.. Yeah not gonna happen especially if you ask for it, be more kind next time and you'll get a decent tip lady...
author: Omar C.

description:
This place is a gem if you're looking for authentic Thai food in the Union Square/Tenderloin area of downtown San Francisco. Not only is the food delicious, they serve generous portions at extremely reasonable prices!

I ordered the spring rolls for an appetizer, which were fresh, and the Pad Se-Ew with chicken, which was great. Overall, I spent $17 on dinner and had leftovers of both the appetizer and entree. 

The atmosphere is casual, and the decor is definitely no-frills, but the restaurant is clean and the service is friendly and prompt.
author: Natalie N.

description:
When me and my coworkers discuss the options of what to have for lunch, we often ask, "Cheapy Thai?" "Ok, cheapy Thai, it is!" Yea, we call this place "cheapy Thai"

And that's what you get, cheap Thai food that tastes pretty good. Their Thai tea is also "Thai-person approved" so check this place out for lunch! I don't think anything on the menu is more than $15 and that would be a massive seafood dish.
author: Amanda M.

description: I really loved it!! Came here with some friends and really enjoyed it. They had a great combo special. Great prices
author: Lacey G.

description: Service is very rude. Food is very okay. I did not know what was their problem. Ask for something and the reply you get is OK. Would not go there again .. Smooth thai just on that crossroad is way better.
author: Amit P.

description: Glad that I dined here ... Last week .... Great apps .. A la carte duck was yummy.... Service attentive but rushed .... Will be back
author: Ajay M.

description: Ate here a few times in the last year - food tastes less Americanized compared to other places. There's even a spicy dish with fresh peppercorns. Service is fast.
author: MT Y.

description: Ordered 2 orders of chicken noodle soup with egg noodles and an order of mango and sticky rice to go. Its my bad for not making sure my order was correct as it seems like the person who answered the phone cant understand english...what I got was a brick of hot dry rice and water with some chicken in it and vermicelli noodles. When I called to tell them my order was all wrong the girl who answered the phone told me to bring everything back and they would charge me 3.50 to fix it. This place lost my business entirely.
author: Michael G.

description:
A half dozen of us walked from the Hilton - Real Estate Connect Hotel to John's Grill (home of the Maltese Falcon) ... the wait was an hour, so we went back towards the Hilton and saw the sign for "The Old Siam Thai Restaurant"

I wasn't expecting much.

Delighted I was wrong!  The spicy seafood dish (mild spicy had a bit of a kick) was plentiful, inexpensive, and superb.  

That's a winning combination when you can pay a lot more for much less in Downtown San Francisco.  Total Bill, including Mint Lemonade, was about $13 or so.

Try it - you'll like it!
author: Ira S.

description: The hubs and I were in San Francisco for our honeymoon and stayed cats corner at the Nikko Hotel. Boy am I glad we stayed there! We were just minutes from this great  little place! We don't ever eat at the same place more than once when we're on vacation, but we couldn't resist! We ate here 3 times during our week stay in SF. We loved the food! Their pad thai, pad siew, and thai fried rice are all delicious! We'll be coming back next time we're in town :)
author: Monica B.

description: Don't get the beef larb!  Too grisly!  I love larb. Served beautifully, until your into it, you don't know.  Asked for medium spicy and received it no spicy. The lemon grass chicken was excellent.
author: Lori H.

description:
I work nearby this wonderful hole in the wall restaurant and would give it 2 thumbs up and a pat on the belly!! 
If you are trying to come in for a quick lunch, be sure to come early because there is a lunch crowd Monday through Friday. 

Overall the service is a 3... in the sense that they do refill water and drinks quickly with a smile, however, if you are looking for a corporate enforced policy of eye contact and convo, you are in the wrong place. They are not there for small chat or story time. 

The food is a 5! I have loved everything I have ordered. My favorite is the spring rolls, Pa Ram (peanut sauce) chicken and the pineapple rice. As for price, you can't beat their lunch special or any of the entrees. Super reasonable!!! And the amount of food requires a tomorrow bag, unless you want to unbutton your pants... 

Overall, excellent food!!!!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Bad. I took a group of people there. The service was super bad. all the dishes came out not at the same time. Mine came first, and I noticed it was something different after eating four bites. It was pork rather than chicken. I told them and she took it to the kitchen. She them brought it back and said it was someone elses that i was sitting with and gave it to him after i had already eaten some. If that wasn't bad enough, twoof us waited over 20 minutes after the first entree was served. Water was not refilled (it was busy, but still!). worst OF ALL THE FOOD WAS not good. i HOPE THIS PLACE GOES OUT OF BUSINESS SOON!
author: S. G.

description: I would have never thought to have stumbled upon my new favorite dessert in a Thai restaurant but wow! EVERYONE should try the deep-fried, Roti stuffed, nutella covered banana with a side of Taro ice cream.. O_o mind blown.
author: Eric G.

description:
My boyfriend and I went here the other day and we each got their lunch special. So much food for ten dollars!

I can honestly say that, though this wasn't the best Thai I've ever had, it was pretty darn tasty. I got the red curry and asked for it Thai spicy - it was spicy, but it only got me sweating the tiniest bit toward the end; that's okay though, because it was pretty yummy otherwise. He got the yellow curry which was sweet and flavorful.

The special came with Pad Thai which, if I liked Pad Thai, would probably have been good. I tried it and it's still not my thing, so I don't factor that into my review. To me, that dish is basically the same everywhere, and I don't eat it anyway.

It also came with fried rice, which I didn't really like, and an appetizer. I got their version of samosas, which were pretty good. I dipped it in the sweet/sour sauce they brought, and it was a nice touch.

I also got the Tom Kha soup, which was delicious. Warm and with a little bit of spice, just the way it's supposed to be. So good!

The service wasn't the best, especially considering it was fairly empty when we went, but it wasn't bad enough to really take away from the experience. Plus, the wait staff was pretty friendly.

Overall, I'd recommend this place if you're in the neighborhood and want Thai.
author: Ari A.

description:
Came here again because I had fond memories of the first time (yeah it's been this long since I came back, there's a lot of spots to choose from in Union Square!). I am pleased to say this place hasn't slacked a bit. The food is just as good and just as reasonably priced. 
I was seated promptly and while the place wasn't hopping at 3 pm, there were a few occupied tables, which is always a good thing. 
I got the combo again (it's 10.99 now) and I had shrimp rolls and chicken panang curry. Comes with fried rice and veggie pad thai, an extra 2 bucks gets you soup. I didn't opt for the soup, as I remembered the first time. All that food is plenty! And so it was again. 
Shrimp rolls were tasty and HOT, very crisp. The panang had awesome flavor and lots of sauce. Chicken was tender and juicy, and the veggies were cooked but not soggy, which I appreciate. I hate soggy vegetables. I ate till I was full, and still had half a plate of pad thai left. The waiters were good at keeping my water refilled and asking if I needed anything, friendly but not intrusive. 
Thai iced tea is always a winner, their ice is kinda crunchy which I like. 
Good value for the amount and quality of the food. Definitely stop here if you're in the area. Mid day was no problem, might be a bit sketch at night, it is skirting the Loin.
author: Jamie B.

description: Disgusting!! The place is so dirty! I ordered the pad se ew and it was mediocre. That wasn't even the worst part. I saw a ROACH scurry across the floor when I was eating...Fucking nasty!!! Don't go here unless you like dirty cheap food...NEVER AGAIN
author: James F.

description:
Long day of meetings, and I am tired and hungry. Noticed a bunch of Thai places near the hotel, so I ask the concierge which is best. He says Old Siam - he and his colleagues frequent the place and it's top notch. 

I placed an order to go: the spicy eggplant with pork rice plate and wonton soup. While waiting, I peered into the kitchen - some serious wokking going on in there!

They packaged my goodies to go with extra napkins, plastic forks/spoons, and chopsticks and I was on my way.

The food was fabulous. The eggplant was melt in your mouth good. Not as spicy as I would have liked (I should have said extra spicy), but it had some heat to it. Lots of garlic flavor. The pork in the dish was done well. And there was plenty of it all.

The wonton soup was a mixed bag. The broth was a bit greasy, but had great flavor. The wontons were delish, and I loved the  Chinese greens. Don't see that as often I'd like, so that was a nice surprise! The roast pork slices in the soup were a bit grizzly and sliced unevenly (some were super thick, some thin, some half thick-half thin). 

Prices are very reasonable - esp for SF. My feast was about $15. 

Overall, it was a good dinner. Lots of interesting things on the menu. Will have to try some more items next time!
author: HAnne D.

description:
Can't believe it myself, but this has to be the first time I've eaten in a Thai place. Okay, I'm from Michigan, but still. 

End result, just what a city restaurant should be: busy, reasonable prices, fast service, not pretentious. And fresh, quality food. Now for the longer story:

Busy place on a Monday night is a good sign. Other single people eating there, so I didn't feel out of place. Prices looked pretty reasonable.

I had a Chang beer, which was just 'okay'. 

What I should have done before I ordered is watched the video monitor with lots of quality pictures of quite a few dishes.

But I had my nose in the very long menu, and picked Mango Curry. The menu said 'mild', but I would put at 'medium'. But good depth of flavor, and quite a bit of mango, plus small pieces of chicken. The curry sauce was more soupy than english-style curry I've had, so I just fished out the good stuff mainly. 

The bowl retained its heat so well, that made it almost as challenging to eat as the medium spice level. (Challenging, doesn't mean bad.)

To cleanse my palate, I chose coconut ice cream. It was very cold, so it wanted to spin in the bowl when trying to get some with a spoon. But very rich and tasty. I'm glad I got it!

My first Thai experience, and I think I'll have to use Old Siam to judge all future Thai restaurants I go to, which should be again this week.
author: Dave J.

description: I really can't ask for much more than this place when it comes to Thai. Had the green curry (perfectly spicy) and the fresh shrimp rolls. Both delicious + authentic.
author: Joseph W.

description:
Cheap tasty Thai in the Union Square area.

They have a dinner special $8.95 for an appetizer, entree, side of fried rice and pad thai.  No, that's not a misprint.  Yes, it did turn into three seperate meals for me.  Woohoo!  Their service leaves a little to be desired - it was pretty slow and not that friendly - but they seemingly make up for it in decent food at cheap prices.  I don't know that I'd normally choose to eat Thai in this area, for a number of reasons, but if I'm in the area, I wouldn't turn it down.
author: Adam T.

description: Got the Pad Thai, it was a little off...
author: Michael E.

description: Delicious!  The Siam duck is highly recommended. Duck noodle soup was good. Clean and friendly.  Good prices.
author: R R.

description:
Super-yummy Thai food and a really great buy!! For around $10, had a meal that included a wide choice of appetizers (I got chicken satay), veggie pad thai, rice, and a decent sized entree (lots of options; I got green curry chicken).

Wouldn't say the ambience was great and it wasn't especially sparkling clean. Service was quick and polite.
author: Jorie M.

description:
A disappointment. My friends wanted to come here because it was near our hotels and our conference was at the Moscone Center. The location is ideal.

That said, the food was mediocre at best. We ordered 4 dishes -  Tom Yum Gai Soup to start, Pad See Ew, Pineapple fried rice and the salmon green curry. The soup was basic and since it was cold outside, a welcome starter. It was tangy sour but lacked the lemon grass flavor.

Pad see Ew- They used the skinny rice noodles like you would find in a Pad Thai preparation, instead of the wider, flat rice noodles. Not only bland, but no flavor. I used the curry sauce added to the noodles for it to be edible. DO NOT RECOMMEND.

Pineapple fried rice was bland. Lots of curry powder thrown in as they cooked the rice, so it coated the rice with a gritty powder taste. Pineapple, chicken and some cashew nuts were tossed in as well.

The salmon green curry was okay. The salmon was not fresh and overcooked. The green curry however was flavorful. We ordered Medium and there was a little heat.

Overall, I would not come back for the food.

The service was inattentive and lacking -  the worst Thai restaurant in terms of service that I have encountered. I think that it must have been a really off night. However, first impressions do count. I had to chase down the waitress to seat us after a 30 minute wait. She tried to seat some folks who just walked in the door, brushing off the sign up sheet. Then she walked away without giving us menus. After 5 minutes. I just got up and grabbed the menus from the front. Another 10 minutes later, someone came to take our order. When we got our food, we had to move our empty soup bowls and beer bottles to a nearby bench to have room for our plates and food. The extra dishes, bowls and bottles were never picked up. We were never offered a refill for water or even asked if we wanted another drink. All I can say is that I was happy to pay and leave, I just wanted to leave behind that disappointing experience.
author: Kiki D.

description:
I stumbled across this place during my lunch hour. Happy to try something new, I was hopeful that I had found another gem in the city. Too bad this wasn't really one of them. 

Since it was my first time, I wanted a little variety so I had the lunch combination which came with fried rice, vegetable pad thai, and two entree choices. I went with the chicken satay and the BBQ chicken.

1. Fried rice -- pretty plain stuff. It was primarily just white rice and some scrambled eggs. Bland to say the least.

2. Vegetable pad thai -- This was better than the fried rice but the sauce they used for the noodles seemed artificial. Maybe, it's because I am accustomed to a different flavor for pad thai but this wasn't so great. Also, the vegetables were undercooked.

3. Chicken satay -- I liked it. It came with some peanut sauce and was pretty tasty. Too bad there were only two skewers. 

4. BBQ Chicken -- Probably my favorite item out of the four choices. Juicy chicken that was cooked just right. 

All this for about $10, which isn't too bad.

Waitresses are very nice and prompt.

Normally, I'd probably give this place a 3 star as it was an average Thai place. Nothing special. However, just as a finished eating, I saw a pretty large bug crawling up the wall near my table. Maybe, it was just a freak accident and this was a rare occurrence but it still made me question the cleanliness of the restaurant. Thus, I docked off 1 star. 

I'm unlikely to come here again....at least for lunch. Based on other reviews, it looks like their dinner food could be better. However, I'll be more hesitant until I can confirm the sanitation level of the place is up to par.

2 stars.
author: Jonathan L.

description: Wow! Best tom yum soup I've ever had! Were from Australia and were in San Fran for 1 night so we decided to go somewhere close by and this place was right across our hotel.  I thought australia had the best tom yum soup - I guess not! Def recommend this place!
author: Irene M.

description:
Bombed into SF with my fiancee for her birthday.  Stayed at the Parc 55 Hotel across from the Old Siam (nice hotel BTW).  I was going to take her to the Thai place inside the Parc 55, but the embiance was "fast foody" like a panda xpress (can't say anything about the food, and I understand they're now renovating the joint).  Anyhow, right across the street was The Old Siam. We were not looking for anything fancy, and this place fit the bill.  The interior was cozy enough and the staff were very friendly.   We've both been to Thailand and South East Asia, love the food...so we kinda know our stuff.

First off, as others have mentioned, they dropped avocado into their fresh spring roll.  Wonderfully done, take those things to a new level.  Next, I'm a big fan of Pad See Ew and theirs was both delish as well as pretty authentic to what I've had in Thailand, definitely enjoyed.  My finacee had the Mango Red curry at the waiter's recommendation.  Our taste buds did a little dance over that sweet and tangy dish!

All in all, we were glad we made the stop.  Good authentic Thai food, swift service, and accomodating staff.

No mistakes made here.
author: Matthew C.

description: I only come here for lunch since i work close by.  I love the Golden Pouches. I mean, how can you not love a fried pouch of curried potatoes and veggies?! The lunch specials are a pretty good deal, but I think Smooth Thai across the street has a better lunch special menu and price. I've tried a variety of stuff off the menu and have never disliked anything I ordered.
author: Janny N.

description: I stumbled across this place as I am staying across the road and really enjoyed it! The food was fresh, well cooked and flavorful. Spices in the curry were well balanced and the egg rolls were delish. Service was also great, staff friendly, accomodating and helpful.
author: Maree M.

description: I always order food to go, never really eat onsite. All I can is, the beef green curry I ordered was okay; I was  dissapointed that there wasn't that much beef on my food but the sauce they gave me was more than enough to fill me up.
author: Daryl R.

description: my all-time favourite thai restaurant in downtown sf.
author: Chadwick H.

description: Authentic, tasty Thai food, generous portions, attentive service. Despite the touristy location, no tourists were visible on our visit. We shared Tom Yum Gsi, spicy pan fried noodles and a vegetarian curry for two. We were more than full, with just enough room left for mango sticky rice. I would certainly go back.
author: Doglike G.

description:
I think I'm going to take these guys down a notch since my last visit was not nearly as impressive as my first. First of all, the prices seemed a bit higher than before. The beers were $4 for a bottle, which is decent, I guess, but kinda steep considering the 24 oz.  at the airport are $8. My friend and i each got one of the combos. they were $10 for a good amout of food. I wanted the red curry though with duck, which cost me $2 more. I also added a soup for $2. In addition, the combo came with 2 Chicken sates which were delectable, vegetarian pad thai, which was comparable to what I had in Chiang Mai, meh, vegetarian fried rice which was very delicious and nicely caramelized by the wok, and I got the red curry with duck, which was very good also, but not quite as good as i remembered it being from my last visit. 

After the meal, I felt like I had ended up spending a lot of money, because I had. I also felt like I would rather have gone across the street to try the (New?) Siam. next time!
author: Miguel V.

description:
This is one of my favorite Thai restaurant in the city. It's so good and authentic. Prices aren't expensive, portions are average but the drunken flat rice noodle, pineapple fried rice, and Thia boat noodles are must order! 

It's at a busy location so good luck finding street parking, but it's conveniently located near a Bart station. 

You will probably spend around $16 for an entree and a drink. But I always recommend family style so everyone can try everything. 

Atmosphere: not noisy, nice date place, great for a crowd as well, it's clean
author: Clairy S.

description:
I ordered the chicken satay.. not bad but I wish it had more flavor.

I will give this place another shot, ordering an actual entree.

An official review to come.. stay tuned.
author: Tram N.

description: Decent thai and good lunch specials.  The tom yum soup was very delicious and just the thing to warm you up on a breezy afternoon.  The panang curry was just OK.  You could kinda taste the savory peanuttyness but ultimately too milky for my liking.  I would try another Thai place before coming back.  I'm just very particular about my panang curry.
author: Stiph N.

description: The food was fantastic, but they forgot to make one of our dishes. We ended up waiting a bit, but the food was great and we all left full!
author: Four F.

description:
ive had my fare share of thai in my life but this place is hands down thee best ive ever had!! 
me and my cousin (whos in town from phily) had a horrifying day filled with crackheads druling on themselves, a terrible doubledecker bus rid going thru terrible fog on the golden gate and endless walking.. we were originally going to check out chinatown but was almost close to closing down for the night so we decided to come here.
we ordered our beers that came promptly, and when i was tossed between two dishes i asked the server what she suggested and she said "both are very good" i dont blame her. lol. i went with the seafood siam and jesus! i do not regret it! sea scallops, shrimp, fresh large chunks of avocado and mango swimming in a sea of curry. this blew my mind! side of rice and chicken satay as an appetizer! my cousin ordered the braised pork with green bean and roasted peppercorn. her mind was also blown. we were so incredibly satisfied with our insanely awesome meal we personally thanked the chef, who was this adorible 70(ish) year old silver haired thai woman. my cousin kissed her hand! haha! 
i am defineltey coming back here! again and again!
author: Rachel S.

description: The food is fantastic. So flavorful. Service wasn't great; they seated us and forgot to give us menus and we had to ask multiple times for a couple things even though they were not understaffed. Still, delicious food ready in a decent amount of time made it worth it.
author: Anya G.

description:
I think this place is just the average. I ordered lunch combo with Tom-Yum soup, and everything tasted OK but not surprised me. I say Tom-yum is slightly better than the average. 

The good point in this restaurant you can enjoy several items with a goo price in lunch time. Lunch combo has curry, pad-thai and spring roll and we can get soup for just $2 or $3. If you miss Thai food, go to this place :-)
author: Machiruda Y.

description: Veggie food was good . Wish they had more veggie curries. Service was ok but time for the dish to come was longer than usual.Liked their thai icea tea. Ambience good. Cleanliness good.
author: Katty D.

description:
I ordered take-out here the other day: pad thai and chicken satay. 

The chicken satay was mediocre. Nothing special, about four skewers. I could probably make it at home. It came with this really good peanut sauce that I ended up pouring over my pad thai.

The pad thai was really good and for about seven bucks, the portions were pretty big. I really liked the big chunks of tofu and the bits of peanuts don't overpower the dish. 

Although it looks pretty run-down on the outside, it's a really nice restaurant on the inside. It's one of the first restaurants I've found in Union Square that is reasonably priced AND decent on the inside. The lady who helped me was really friendly too. It felt great to see finally see a smile that day. Definitely coming back
author: kathleen d.

description: Food was okay. Mostly too spicy. The price was pretty high for what you get and the service was terrible. Won't come again or recommend. And if you need receipts for business expenses, tuck them away somewhere safe because this place can't (or won't) reprint receipts if you're not from the city.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Across the street from the newer Siam restaurant in the Parc 55 hotel, this Old Siam Thai restaurant offers a good menu of tasty Thai and other fusion dishes.

I ordered the fresh rolls and soups - very tasty.  The rolls had avocado in it.  Why didn't I think of that?  It was very good.  The soup was a bit bland, but with their table side condiments, it turned out to be more than expected.  

Don't let the exterior fool you, the food is good.
author: Bo T.

description:
I work nearby and came here with a co-worker last week to try it out. He ordered the pad thai ($7.25), a thai iced tea ($2?), and I a pad se-ew ($7.25), plus spring rolls (I think it was ~$5).

I feel full just reminiscing about it.

The presentation for his pad thai was quite nice--noodles in one corner and an artfully displayed lot of unrelated produce on the other. From what I tried, the noodles were chewy and springy, a definite plus. The only complaint I have is that the shrimp and chicken in the dish were a bit tough from being over-cooked.

The presentation of my pad se-ew was not as glamourous--no garnish or fancy what have you--but still tasted alright nonetheless. I'm a sucker for Chinese broccoli, and there was a good amount mixed in this dish. The flat rice noodles were evenly coated brown, and were flavourful without being oily of overbearing. I found the portion rather generous, finished half and ended up saving the rest for dinner.

The spring rolls were crispy and hot with obviously fresh ingredients inside. I want to say that garnish is relatively useless and wasteful, but it just made it pop by jazzing up half the plate. I believe it came with four rolls, all cut in half, making that a total of eight pieces.

And the Thai iced tea! Oh man. I had a sip but that was all I needed. It's pretty good here: creamy, and perhaps a bit sweet for my taste.

Overall, decent prices for good food. If you're looking for some Thai food and you're in the area, I'd recommend The Old Siam.
author: Alice K.

description: Good Pad Thai, not the best I've ever had but good.  Wasn't very spicy, should have asked if they could make it spicier for me.  Very reasonably priced.
author: Aaron T.

description: I didn't come here with the highest expectations, because I usually don't like most restaurants in the Union Square area.  But I was surprised to find that this place was pretty good.  The only thing I thought was weird was that there was a huge column in front of the doors so it could be a little tricky to get in if you're on the heavier side.
author: Joe N.

description:
My girl and I wandered in here during a spur of the moment trip to San Francisco looking for a light late evening dinner close to our hotel. After perusing the menu and agonizing over a decision of fish or chicken (two notoriously indecisive Libras can drag that out ALL DAY) we settled on three things.

Pineapple fried rice (she'd never tried it,) satay chicken, and pepper garlic (?) prawns. So much for a light meal...

The prawns were HUGE (at least by my American standards. The girl's a half Aussie so she wasn't as impressed) and they gave us six. Crunchy, salty, garlicy and full of flavor. I even ate they shells! The fried rice was sweet with big chunks of pineapple and a perfect compliment to the saltiness of the prawns. The 5 skewers of chicken were juicy with a creamy satay sauce that was a change from the chunky variety I find in LA. 

Thank goodness everything was delicious as we had no fridge to take leftovers. Leaving anything behind would be tantamount to sin. 
 
Great service with a decent price. I'm going back next time I'm in town.
author: Dom R.

description: I wish I could give the restaurant five stars, but it was not the best meal that I have ever had at a Thai restaurant.  Massuman Curry is my "go to" meal.  The vegetables were cooked perfectly, but I didn't like that the only meat options were lamb or pork.  I don't like either and wished chicken or tofu was an option.  However, the Thai iced tea was some of the best that I have ever had.
author: Amanda S.

description:
The large and bright green neon sign that marks this restaurant on the corner of Ellis and Mason made me a little suspicious that it would be highway robbery on my wallet just like Tian Sing up the block, but thankfully it was pretty good value-wise for the portions served. My friend and I didn't take advantage of the dinner special menu when we went, instead choosing our own rice plates...for him, the spicy seafood, and for me - duck fried rice. Food arrived pretty quickly...within 15 minutes, and overall tasty. I really enjoyed my fried rice, although I wished there was more duck meat vs. skin. The spicy seafood had a great sauce and lots of calamari, but I found it lacked the heat that we both were expecting from a Thai dish marked spicy. We also ended up at a table that didn't have any condiments on it, while I noticed there were a select few that did have the sauces at their disposal. 

I wouldn't turn down another visit here, but somehow I still prefer the hustle and bustle vibe that King of Thai on O'Farrell and Bankok Thai on Powell streets have. And I find the dishes there are just as tasty if not more so, as well as being about $2 cheaper per plate.
author: Elaine W.

description: I just love, love, love this place.  Great portions of food and reasonably priced.  Watch out for the big post at the entrance...you may get a concussion!
author: Robert M.

description: Was looking for a quick bite for dinner before a conference started.  Asked the concierge at the Hyatt, and this was one of the places he recommended.  It's a corner restaurant, so easy to find.  I ordered the Pad Sew Ew and a Thai iced tea.  Food hit the spot, which made me happy.  Service was also quick and friendly.  Can't beat that!
author: Christy L.

description: All I could ask for... Tasty, fast, friendly, very reasonable prices. Great Chinese broccoli and tofu, as well as coconut soup!
author: Tristan L.

description: Been coming here for years every time I visit San Francisco. I love there Panang Curry. The waiters were very attentive and friendly.  This place never fails to please! I'd say the best Thai restaurant in the Union Square area!
author: Randy S.

description:
You can trust this place for a decent Thai meal.
The service was a bit too slow (but there was a group who seemed to have ordered quite a lot of things) although not all the table were used.
The Green cury was tasty, although a bit too sweet for my taste. I think we can say the same for the other meals : a bit too much sugar... but this was fine.
author: Tristan L.

description: Lao dish Tom Zaab Delicous!!!!!!!!
author: Big M.

description: I stumbled upon Old Siam Thai while looking for Asian food in San Francisco. I'm glad I tried it out. The staff was very pleasant, and my takeout food was ready in a hurry. The Pad See Eew was very good indeed. It was spicy like I wanted, fresh, and tasty. I liked their use of broccolini in place of regular broccoli... higher quality. I recommend giving this place a try. A warm welcome and delicious food at a low price!
author: Justin H.

description: Perfect. Got hot & sour soup with shrimp, shrimp and asparagus stir fry (added chicken for $2 extra), Thai fried rice with pork, and mango with sticky rice.  All dishes were excellent/delicious.  Didn't skimp on shrimp or the meats.  Told me that adding chicken was $2 extra. Ask for to go menu which they provided and told me prices are not current.  I don't like surprises and expected the chicken would cost extra but was nice the waitress mentioned it and ask if it was ok.  All food was authentic and made fresh.  They had constant flow of customers and was very busy.  Overall very pleasant.  Wouldn't suggest to go there for date night. Go to Kin Lhao for that. It's across the street in the Parc 55 Hilton where I stayed.  Didn't eat there as they had no table available for 1 person and bar was full. They had a communal table but no thanks. Saw The Old Siam Thai across the street so went.  Very pleased.
author: K C.

description:
There were some reviews saying this was a little hole in the wall but I thought it looked fine inside. The dining area and plate presentation were attractive enough and the service was very fast.

 My fiance liked the curry he had but I thought my pad thai was merely so-so. They used smaller noodles than I was am familiar with and the sauce was a little redder, this itself was not bad, just different. However, the noodles seemed a bit rubbery and clumpy at times. The prices were good, though I feel like it was mostly noodle with very little tofu or shrimp.
author: Niccole P.

description: Wednesday night dinner after a day of shopping.   Service was attentive.  Ordered garlic calamari and red curry chicken.  Food came quickly and was very tasty!  Sticky rice not so good as it had texture of something that was microwaved before serving.  Steamed rice was fine.  Would go again!  Good value for the price!!
author: Lee M.

description: Fantastic!!!! Best thia I have had in awhile. Highly recommend to anyone staying in the nearby hilton. Very convenient and delicious. Great service too :)
author: Cortney B.

description: Great food. Best for friends or laughs rather than a date night. Great food though.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Came to this restaurant on Saturday night. The  place was 60% full. When we entered the door, the waitress greeted us and showed our table. I ordered Kao Soy and my friends order pad thai, fried rice, and pork belly special from their menu. My Kao Soy was really good, I thought, a little bit too sweet, but I like sweet. I tasted my friend's pad thai and it was also delicious. Lots of flavor and good amount of portion for the price you are paying. It is slightly more expensive, but the place is very close to Union Square.The service was good. i would come back to try their other dishes if I were to go to Union Square again.
author: Bibi B.

description:
I have been waiting for this place to reopen & curious to see if it would be as good as it was before.  Granted, Siam Thai is right across the street & that place rocks, but it's always good to have options.  There is no shortage of Thai restaurants in this area & I aim to try them all!

The decor is much nicer than before & everything just looks cleaner.  

I had the salmon with green curry for lunch.  Generous portions & very fresh veggies.  I just love it when you are served a piping hot bowl of curry & the veggies are slightly crunchy.  Yum!  All of the tables around me had different dishes & they all looked delicious.  Next time I'll try the soup...it comes in a bowl bigger than your head.  I heard the table next to me slurping away.  That's a good sign.
author: Erin S.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up!  I came here for the first time based on a recommendation from Ed U.  After three visits, I can assertively say that the food is much better to that at the various King of Thai Noodle Houses (or as I like to say King of Rubbery Chicken).  Although the menu at Old Siam is relatively similar to KOT's, the quality is supperior.

I've had green curry chicken rice plate, chicken pad thai, and vegetarian egg rolls on separate occasions.  I recommend all three.  The chicken isn't all dried out and old tasing the way they are at KOT and the egg rolls are fresh from the fryer crisp without being oily.

The location isn't the greatest at night, but it's right across the street from the Hilton and the Parc 55 Hotel.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: Huge portions, great food, and cheap specials (~$9.95 lunch). The coconut milk soup was phenom. The food comes out rather quickly but is hot and extremely delicious.
author: Natalie G.

description:
Basically it's gets 5 for food, and a 3 for service, and if my math skills serve me right, 4 is the average.

All of the prices were reasonable and we got decent portion.  I got an appetizer (chicken satay) and entree (BBQ Thai Pork) combo.  Came with Pad Thai as well, for like $9.  My boyfriend got the Mango Curry and he loved it.  Food was very flavorful and was served super fast.

The servers were not the most attentive and they kind of attacked us when we walked it by screaming "How many" across the restaurant, rushed us to order and we're that helpful.  It was not good, but it wasn't terrible.

The food totally made up for it, so I would go back anytime.
Also close location to Civic Center, BART and all that jazz.
author: Terran O.

description: Everytime my partner and I have been here, which is pretty often, we always have good food and good service. I have been coming to this place ever since it was a hole in the wall Thai joint. Can't go wrong here for good Thai food.
author: D. D.

description: I was so relieved cuz the food was GOOD! I was skeptical when they gave me a glass of water that was warm and had those little bubbles that tells you it's been sitting for awhile. I tried out the $10 dinner combo with red beef curry, chicken satay, rice, and tofu pad thai. The service was pretty good. The food came out fast and it was hot. I checked out four other restaurants on this block and this was the cheapest one by a long shot.
author: Sarah S.

description: I was going to give this joint 3 stars for decent food, service, and portion sizes, but then I remembered that they have Singha bottles for $3.25 and I gave it 4.
author: Allison S.

description:
This place is good! The prices are reasonable, the portions are decent, and the food tastes great! My group and I got a soup (I forgot which one...), seafood salad, yellow curry, eggplant w/ chicken, bbq chicken, and pad thai. everything came out relatively quickly. 

-1 star for the waitress who we tried to flag down 5 times and totally ignored us (albeit, this wasn't 5 separate occasions, it was just 5 times in the span of 30 seconds)

And why is there this awkward pillar in front of the entrance?
author: Pauline S.

description: Clean setting and environment. Fast service and in a very neat and precise manner.  Reasonable prices for tasty food.
author: R C.

description:
Came here after a friend's gig at the Apple store & the staff were very gracious about accommodating our large group.  We arrived in clumps and were eventually 15. 

We all ordered at different times, lots of confusion (created by us) but they were still all so friendly and kept the tea coming.  So much tea, we eventually all got to try out the unisex  restroom.

No alcohol license yet.  If I went back, I'd order a mint lemonade.

Thought and care has gone into the interior.  They have a lion fountain!

The flavor of my spring roll was great but I felt that the outside was a bit mushier than I'd like.  Everyone else enjoyed their food.

I would never make a special trip back here (I have my regular Thai place, of course)  but will go back again if in the area.
author: Megan G.

description: Nice simple Thai restaurant.  Food was fresh and served quickly.  Everything was very tasty - nothing out of the ordinary, but certainly good and well worth the price.  We were headed for a show up the street and had leftovers.  They kindly boxed them and held them for us to pick up after the theater - a very nice bit of extra service.  We'll be back.
author: Andrew P.

description: Great food!!!!!  My best friend and I both love Thai food. We shared the spicy fisherman and chicken pad thai. We stayed at hotel close by and stumbled across this great restaurant for dinner. We were not disappointed!
author: Stacie C.

description:
I used to go to this place when it was Red's Corner...but that was for a different reason entirely ;-) (God I LOVED that bar). 

For the past 7 years I've been going to King of Thai for my Thai food needs, but that ends today. I'm tired of them calling the shots, opening whenever they want, forgetting my Thai Ice Tea and a number of other offenses. I've let it go because I believed they were the best in the area. 

Today, when they didn't answer their phone until 11:30 am (they supposedly open at 11:00 am) and the girl who answered rudely told me that she wasn't ready to open yet and to call back in 20 minutes, I decided that our time together is through. A friend of mine, at work suggested Old Siam. She said she had been there and liked it.

I figured I'd give it a shot and I am so glad I did!

Friendly service. Hardy portions. Delicious Flavors.

Hello Old Siam. Goodbye King of Thai!
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Great food and even better service plus its cheap food for the area. This place is a for sure must try.
author: Jacob M.

description: Our server was too rude, and if she behaved politely we would have left more than 18% of tip. But she already added the 18% of tip into our bill, which she doesn't deserve to get. It's bullshit.
author: Soyoung P.

description: I got take-out - pad thai - and it was SO delicious!!!!!  They were very friendly & the food was ready pretty quickly.  Definitely will go again!
author: Sam G.

description:
The $9.95 Special Combo (appetizer, rice, entree, plus pad thai) was definitely worth the money. $2 bucks for the Tom yum soup if you added it with your combo. The taste of the food was just too seasoned for me, it was either too salty or too sweet. THe satay and Tom yum was good. 

It's worth the money to go for the combo but the food is less than average for me.
author: Hebert J.

description: The awful smell that emanated from the back of the restaurant  was more than enough to put me off my food. Although I appreciate their portion sizes (one of the few places I know that gives enough that you're just full), it doesn't compensate for the fact that my noodle soup (which I asked to be made spicy) tasted like red chilli flakes and not much else. Not to mention the smell from hell.
author: Kavita B.

description:
Came here with a couple coworkers and one ordered the wonton soup an when we got our orders they took one bite out of te wonton and it was disgusting. If you smelled it it was sour and spoiled. We complained and they took it back and replaced it with something else. We ate happily thinking they had given us the other order for free but nope! They changed the order and charged us for the other item...you gave us spoiled wonton that we ate...the least you could do was offer a free meal. 

Lame lots more Thai places out there in that neighborhood.
author: Ed C.

description: I would love to rate the food in this place next time when I actually decide to give this place another chance. One star is what they deserve for the service. The table I got was dirty with a leftover coffee cup from a previous customer. I was in a hurry and ordered the food. 30 minutes later one waitress told me that my order should be ready soon. It was not the case, in a few minutes another waitress asked me to repeat my order, and did not even apologized.  I left. Terrible service!
author: igor k.

description:
I am so ecstatic this place opened again. Living in the TL, there are plenty of Thai places to choose from, but if you want savory, flavorful food, you must come here.

Yes, the prices are slightly higher than before the renovations, but even then, they are cheaper than other popular trendy Thai places in the area. The quality is still superb and the portions large. Plus, they now accept credit cards.

My passion is curry, and I'm often disappointed by Yelp's high-ranked places that serve a mediocre, watered-down imitation. Old Siam's curry is rich, spicy and pops with flavor. Red is my favorite, but their green and yellow curries are also excellent. My only criticism (not just here, but at most Thai places) is a lack of vegetables in the curry. Bamboo shoots, carrots and bell peppers are fine, but any meat choice tends to drown out the balance. I guess this is great if you're feeling exceptionally carnivorous, but I find myself ordering the vegetarian Gang Pak more often.

The eggplant, green bean and duck noodle soup dishes are all wonderful here. And as much as I love and respect Osha, Old Siam's Spicy Thai Pan-Fried rice noodles wins hands-down. You get that fantastic smoky charred wok flavor that takes you back to eating at a stall on the side of a Bangkok road. Garlicky, chewy and just the right amount of oil. Definitely a late-night comfort food. Unfortunately, Old Siam is only open until 11pm at the latest.

Located where it is, the place is usually filled with tourists from Union Square and neighboring hotels. Just ignore the backpacks and SF maps unfurled across people's tables. The new decor is nice but not pretentious. The staff is super friendly and always smiling. But the food is what stands out the most. But hey, that's what you would expect from a restaurant, right?
author: David N.

description:
