Best Thai restaurant in San Francisco! No doubt! I even park illegally just to get some food from them. 

Pad Thai - Hot, steamy and delicious
Panang Chicken - Awesomely declicious. Makes me drool everytime
Thai Tea -  GREAT! I secretly drink out of the bf's cup when he's in the restroom :)

Strongly Recommended! If you go else where, you're MISSING OUT!
author: Impatient K.

description: I was starving and I was looking for a filling meal. What attracted me to this places versus the one across the street was the smell. I know what a real Thai food place smells like and they smelled pretty good. I walked in at about 2pm on a Sunday, was seated immediately (there were only a few customers), atmosphere was pretty quiet aside a conversation or two. I ordered the Pad Thai. The serving was pretty generous, though the noodles were not cooked too well (clumps of noodles stuck together). The tofu and veggies were pretty fresh, the shrimp was ok. The meal was overall satisfactory at most. Service was attentive and polite. Nothing fantastic to write home about, but wouldn't mind eating here again.
author: Marie H.

description: Among some friends we tasted the dinner combo (pad thai, peanutty fried-tofu thing, hot and sour soup) and one of the specials, the salmon and green chili curry. All were super delicious. Everything tasted fresh, presentation was colorful and also reflective of the freshness of ingredients, and the sauces had really great flavor. Our group of critical vegetarians left very very happy. Especially given the prices are so damn reasonable for the amount of food they give you.
author: Jen N.

description:
I ate here twice and I am indeed a fan.  Quite often restaurants in downtown SF are rather expensive. I found Old Siam because I was staying next door at the Nikko.  It looks nondescript and inexpensive.

The food is indeed inexpensive.  About 7 to 8 bucks for a rice platter but the flavors were superb and the portions abundant.

I went there on two occasions.  For appetizers, the fish cake and the fried squid.  Both were excellent!

I also tried the garlic fish. This was fried and though I was expecting a sauce of sorts, it was good without it.  My dinner mate had the yellow curried chicken and it looked great as well.
author: Bill H.

description:
I gave The Old Siam a try for dinner one night after work. While we were able to get seated immediately, I saw that it was reasonably full of other customers happily dining (Mental note: so far so good - crowded restaurant means good food). The decor and ambiance is comfortable enough - though the Christmas icicle lights in mid-July is a head-scratcher.

 I can usually set my expectations based on the size of a menu. The larger the menu the less quality I expect. With almost 100 items in the menu "book" - all priced around $10, I was mentally preparing my self for a mediocre meal.

 I ordered the Jerked Pork appetizer and the Sweet and Sour Chicken Fried Rice. The Jerked Pork was great with a spicy dip which gives it a "buffalo wings" flavor. However, I have mixed feelings for the Sweet and Sour Chicken. The Chicken was perfectly breaded with a light crispy crunch, and was very tender and juicy. The bed of fried rice however, should have been left in the cardboard box it was cooked in and thrown out. Seriously, I don't know how they prepared the rice, but all I could think of while eating it was an old wet cardboard box. Overall, I give The Old Siam good marks - despite the cardboard rice. This is not fine-dinning, and for the price I was generally impressed.
author: Preston R.

description: I went to Old Siam with two friends for supper on Tuesday, 10 December.  The most remarkable thing about this place is the low prices: I had an appetizer sampler and an entree for just under $20, which is seemingly a bargain in Union Square.  Service was efficient but courteous enough, especially considering how busy it was.  Quality of food was good -- not excellent but markedly better than average.
author: Danny B.

description: The Old Siam restaurant was okay food, but it was not spectacular at all. We were there for lunch, so their dinner and/or full menu could be much better than their lunch specials. Everything tasted fine, the place was clean; it just wasn't very impressive. "It's okay," is probably the best description... it's not bad, it's not great, it's just what it is; at least at lunch time and off their lunch specials menu.
author: Brian M.

description: Just OK for my Thai food standards.
author: Mike C.

description:
Everyone in our 10-person office agrees that this is the best Thai food in town!  The mango curry is fantastic!  Also the best Thai Iced Tea around.  They have a delicious special right now as well:  a green curry with avocado.  Delicious!

I like that they can make pretty much anything vegetarian.  Service is a little slow, but not bad enough to take it down a star, especially because it is cheaper than most places of similar quality.
author: Rachael S.

description: This Thai food is delicious! The fried tofu with peanut sauce is to dieee for. When I think San Fransico, I think this place.
author: Nicole L.

description:
So it was our last night in San Fran before catching the red eye back to Chi-town. We were looking for something relatively affordable, quick, and filling. This place did the trick, but didn't "wow" us. The food was definitely cheap - especially for big city standards. I ordered the beef pad thai - and I got a TON of beef pad thai. I've had better in Chicago. I also ordered a thai ice tea - so so. If you're looking for a lot of food for a good price, this is your place.

Note of caution: there were only 5 of us and they added 20% gratuity...I didn't notice until after I added an additional tip... boo
author: Sharon W.

description: Old siam was a nice place for some Asian desert. I got their mango coconut rice and it was delicious. A good sweet for the evening.
author: Sean C.

description:
This review comes from my third time eating at Old Siam Thai.  The two previous times I ate there at the actual restaurant.  That experience pushed me to get take out this time.

The two previous times at Old Siam we had a long wait and I do mean long.  Granted it was the lunch hour but people were just not being served fast enough and if you have to wait over 5 minutes for a beverage, that is too long.  And when you only get 60 minutes you can't wait to be served to enjoy any lunch hour before rushing back to work.

The menu is pretty extensive so I felt a little overwhelmed but pleased at the same time.  Overall I felt the prices were maybe 50 cents too high for the area (it's kinda near the tenderloin even though it's also near a ton of hotels).

The food quality is pretty solid though.  Good solid thai food with a little bit of class, not ghetto thai.  The location is nice on the inside but even with the remodel it feels cramped.  I'll visit it maybe once in a couple of months.
author: Dave S.

description: I visited for lunch and the Pad Thai was overly sweet.  Wait staff was extremely disorganized.  They did not know who was waiting on what table and they tried to give the neighboring table the wrong order.  Seating was friendly and fast but it took awhile to have my order taken.  I ordered soup and instead of coming before my meal it came with my meal.  The Thai Ice Tea met my expectations.
author: Candace B.

description:
I can't believe I never reviewed this!  I found out about this place from a couple of friends.  I've been going here frequently for about two years now.  The staff has always been friendly in my experience, and they aren't slow either.  I've never had to wait more than 30 seconds to get a table also.

Most of the foods here you can't really go wrong with, but then again I tend to order only a few things I'm interested in.  I love the Tom Yum noodle soup with flat rice noodles and the chicken wing appetizers (so GOOD).  The curries have always been good.  I've brought several friends here over time and they like the place.

I like that the food is good and decently priced, and that it's in downtown, which is very convenient.
author: Liz A.

description: In town for a wedding and looking for a place to eat. Yelped for a Thai place and saw that this place is a must try. Cheap, ordered the pad see eww it was very yummy. My wife had the dinner combo includes pad Thai, rice, choice of appetizer and entree for about $9! Sweet...
author: John S.

description:
Had much better Thai in Fremont altogether.

We ordered the chicken pad see ew and the taste didnt come anywhere close to the handful of other thai places I've eaten at.

The combination fried rice is bland - nothing too special.

I'm a little disappointed considering it's right by Powell st...
author: David L.

description: Uh oh, a Thai restaurant in a middle of a metropolitan!  I'm too scared to check if this is going to be authentic.  Okay, so I was brought up in a very Asian community, so even the Thai restaurants are probably Chinese-Thai at the least.  This restaurant is "ok" at its best.  It fills you up to the point where you're satiated, but maybe not stuffed.  We came here for dinner and they served us water at first.  Then they asked us if we wanted anything to drink (okay, don't you see us consuming water already?  I guess you want us to buy your Thai tea now, yes?).  Onto dinner.  We had their vegetarian pad thai special  (with curry) and the pad see ew.  We added the soup for $2, which asn't bad at all.  I was surprised they did not ask us how spicy we wanted the curry, but I guess they went with their intuition and gave us medium (good call.  Thank god we didn't have our mom here or she'd be pissed off since she can't handle spices at all!  haha)  Anyway, what made this restaurant even more "low class" was when the waitress asked us if we wanted dessert.  What?  So you charge for your lil sweet desserts, too?  I don't know, we interpreted that as an Americanized restaurant afterward.  I'm so sorry, I've been frequenting Thai restaurants that actually give you complimentary  (yep, FREE) desserts.  That was a good carbo load dinner for a half marathon though - not too fattening like the previous night!  Won't be coming here unless Subway sandwiches is closed. lol.
author: Janey Y.

description: Old Siam is my favorite Thai restaurant in the Union Square area. I usually order their pad see ew, which is the standard I use to gauge the quality of a Thai restaurant. Old Siam's pad see ew is perfectly prepared: not too greasy, the veggies cooked just right. I went their today and noticed they used Western broccoli this time around rather than the usual Chinese broccoli, which I prefer for its slightly bitter taste. Nonetheless, the pad see ew was just as good as always. Much better IMO than King of Thai Noodle House and Bangkok Noodles. Highly recommended!
author: David W.

description: alil skeptical cuz the outside looked kinda run down but damn it was the best!! i ordered the shrimp and crab spring roll. so bomb i want to go back right now. i ordered the salmon green curry. awesome flavor so good!!! i ate it cold the next day.  more than enough food and they give you legit plastic reusable containers to pack it in. and to top it all off there thai tea with pearls was the best i've ever had. i was so pleased with everything i told our waitress i loved her but i meant the restaurant.  i will be returning to this place best believe... maybe this weekend.
author: Natalia M.

description: i have lived about 50 yards from old siam for 8 years but never went in.  my dog and i pass by their windows several times a day, and i've noticed they're always packed.  ordered the combination fried rice and the fresh rolls and both were obviously made by someone who enjoys working with food.  it was fresh and there was a lot of it.  can't ask for more than that.
author: Matt T.

description: Like most Thai restaurants, this one is completely serviceable, but it's not one that I would bother to eat at again given the other options in the area. Ar Roi is several blocks away and my favorite in the area, if not one of my top worldwide. Anyway, ordered pad ped talay which was a nice mix of seafood but the sauce was not very delicious. Also ordered red curry veggies with tofu, the sauce was thinner than I typically encounter but still good nonetheless.
author: Super D.

description:
This is the only Thai food restaurant in SF that has good food! I've always passed by this place to go to downtown but never acknowledged it because it looked pretty lame from the outside. 

Everyone should check out their special menu! It's worth it because they give you options to choose from and is only $10.00 ! Order the Tom yum chicken soup, it's spicy & hot but very delicious :) They gave me a big plate and I had to have it for to-go ! 

ALSO! Try their Thai iced tea :) 

The only bad thing is that you have to wait for the bathroom and the tables are kind of close together ! And the atmosphere is very casual, nothing fancy. I hate how it's near the Tenderloin neighborhood ! But overall very good place to eat w/ your family !
author: kathy t.

description:
We often eat here when we are downtown because its economical and delicious.  Usually we go when its cold and we want soup, because the hot and sour soup is really good, I ask for it spicy and its barely edible, but I like it that way.

We've had the pad thai and a couple of curries- all good.

The water glasses are large and they keep them full.
author: Brenda B.

description: Not bad at all.  Better than what you would expect from a thai place that close to tenderloin.
author: Charles C.

description:
Went here during Black Friday after a day of shopping.

Ordered the fried rice, tofu, and pork dish. It was clean and delicious. But the portions were kind of small for the price.

I would recommend this place if you want to try Thai food, but not if you're really really hungry.
author: Jimmy P.

description: I always love coming by here for seafood Tom yum noodle whenever coming by the area during workdays. The decor is nice, better than that of the nearby more popular King of Thai noodle by Macy's.
author: H K.

description: We ordered the pad thai, panang curry, and peppered prawns. The pad thai is really good! The prawns were amazing especially if you ask for a side of peanut sauce to dip them in! The curry was mediocre. The rice with mango dessert was the perfect way to end the meal! Definitely will be back!
author: Chauanh D.

description:
my bf and I walked by this place and decided to try it.  to keep it simple, I'll tell you what was good and what was not.

GOOD:  the appetizer we got with fried squid and mushrooms in spice sauce. That was some BOMMBASS squid.  The texture of the squid was really soft and juicy on the inside and the breading was rather light but still crunchy.  The sauce was tangy, sweet, and spicy...So full of flavor that top chef  judges would approve.  Loved it!

GOOD: We had the pan nang curry with the salmon as well.  Very gingery, but i like the thickness of the sauce, and very flavorful..I love the vegetables...mmm green beans....not a bad combo at all.  The salmon fillet was whatever...nothing special.  


The BAD: Do not get the roasted duck over vegetables here....ughhh...I don't know bout you but i like my duck to have crispy skin, the fat to be nice and greasy but not puffy and very tender and juicy meat that comes right of the bone.  The duck here was chewy, overcooked and the flavor was not there, not even with the dipping sauce.  ::SIGH:: so hard to find delicious roast duck...the vegies were good  ithink i only ordered that because i wanted the vegies.

service was good, very friendly and patient, our waitress came to fill water multiple times and we took a long while to make our decision but she didnt' look irritated or anything like some people do when you take a long time. 

not badd not bad...will go for the appetizer again...may try other things?
author: Zu W.

description: Decent carry out Thai. Tom yum soup was very good.
author: Brian C.

description: Old Siam is solid. Price is decent...food is better. Pork fried rice, chicken satay, curries are all good. I work next door to this restaurant and it keeps me comin back at least 3 times a week..and thats a lot of thai.
author: Julian S.

description: Really sad food... Not at all recommended to go. When giving less tip for being served cold food and bad service, the owner confronted me and asked to put more tip.. Spoilt our evening. A complete NO - MUST NOT VISIT
author: Namit R.

description: The service was good and the food was better.  A friend and I were in San Francisco for a concert at the Warfield which is just right around the corner so the location was convenient enough for us to walk to.  Can't remember exactly what I had, but it was from the noodle dish list.  It was a spicy beef and noodle dish with veggies.  The flavor was good and the I was pleased with the portion size.  The plate was less than $8.  If I'm ever in the vicinity, I will definitely visit again.
author: Palei T.

description:
Affordable and delicious! Great vegetarian menu!
I had the fried tofu in peanut sauce and it was just what I was craving.
Four friends and myself walked out very satisfied with our meals and boasting about promoting the place, so here I am promoting it.
author: Keegan L.

description:
I crave the Tom Kai Gai here, if a thai restaurant cant make a yummy broth then I wont be back, but this place has the best tom kai gai I have tasted in the city. 

They closed not long ago for a remodel and I was lost, I crave the yummy food here and am so happy its back. This is the perfect place to visit if you are downtown shopping and want a tasty lunch and did I mention and the prices couldnt be better. 

As for deciding which Siam to go , there are two on this corner, I have tried the siam thai next door and wasnt super impressed.....

Check this place out, sooooo good!!!
author: Kirsty E.

description: As I sat in the restaurant, I could see the sign for the other Siam Thai out the window. I guess Siam Thai is the Starbucks of the edge of the Tenderloin. We spent the day in Union Square and didn't want to spend a bloody fortune on a meal. Enter Old Siam Thai's lunch special. For less than $10 each, we got an appetizer, an entree, fried rice, and pad thai. Top it off with a thai iced tea and it's an awesome meal. I must say that it wasn't full of flavor but it was great for the price and the location. I wish that I would have copied Paul and got the shrimp rolls and the green curry but my chicken satay and barbeque pork weren't bad at all. Especially when they were smothered in hot chili oil. Yum!
author: Randi Y.

description: Had the Pad Thai, Delicious! Clean and great service.
author: Marty T.

description: How did I not review this place yet?! I've been coming here for months now since I work in the area. It has got to be my favorite Thai spot downtown. Looking for a quiet lunch & want Thai? Dread the long wait at King of Thai? Come to Old Siam! I've tried many items on the menu & I've gotta say that I've never been disappointed. The food isn't too oily compared to other Thai restaurants in the area & service is pretty fast. Their Thai garlic fried rice is so yummy. Not too garlicky nor oniony. I normally order the Thai BBQ chicken over fried rice, BBQ pork wonton soup, & mango curry. They also have roti! What Thai spot in downtown offers roti? The Old Siam is what I know of. Some dishes on their menu is a bit more extensive than Bangkok & Colliander, but its totally worth it. They also have awesome lunch specials! Staff is always friendly & attentive. The restaurant is a bit small, so come with a small group or a date. Looking for a place to fill you up under $10? Whocares about all the crackheads walking around & go to The Old Siam.
author: BrendaJoy G.

description: I found this place on yelp, and it didn't disappoint! My friend and I got dinner here after work. It was empty when we got there at 6pm on a Thursday, but filled up within the hour. I got the yellow curry combo with coconut soup. Delicious. And the portions were fairly large. It's a hole-in-the-wall place; I would come back again for dinner with friends. I don't think it's date worthy.
author: Corinthia C.

description: This restaurant is on the corner next to my office.  Does a pretty brisk business for lunch and dinner.  Having been spoiled by having Manora Thai and Basil by my old office, Old Siam had a high bar to jump with me and so far, not quite.  I've had pad thai, tom kha gai, tom yum gai and some of the curries.  All are ok but not great.  The flavors don't jump out like I feel they should and the ingredients tend to meld together.  Not sure if it's just the chef or other things.  It's decent but not up to the level I think they should be.
author: Ron T.

description:
I stopped in here the other night. I was very hungry and tired, and just wanted to grab a bite to eat near my hotel. I did not have high hopes as i was assuming this was going to be a generic thai place like so many others i have tried.

So i ordered a cup of chicken tom yum soup and spicy beef and basil dish, both extra spicy.

The tom yum i got was a rather large bowl, and filled with meat and vegetables. The broth was very tasty, and really tasted good. I was very impressed.

The spicy beef dish was a lot different from what i usually get when i order this dish. The plate consisted of what looked like ground beef with rd and green peppers. I was surprised, as i was not expecting that . The taste however won me over. Very tasty and savory sauce, and the beef, while ground, was actually pretty good. I missed the onions usually in the dish, but overall it was pretty good. 

I think i am going to go back for another cup of tom yum before i leave town.
author: Andy C.

description: This is one of the fanciest Thai restaurants I've ever been to, yet it's relatively cheap. I didn't stay long enough to bask in its beauty because I had to go back to work, but I did stay long enough to wait for my takeout. The squid, shrimp, noodle in some kind of red soup tasted very interesting. It was also quite spicy, which I liked. I'm totally coming back next time on my day off.
author: Alex Y.

description: Old Siam was quite a find.  Four of us went for dinner on Saturday and had a great meal.  Starting off, we split two appetizer plates, then ordered four entrees -- two curries (green w/ salmon and eggplant, red w/ chicken), a prawn dish and a crab soup.  The portions were generous, the food was pleasantly spicy but not too hot (I usually prefer my curries hotter, but we were considering some tastebuds not used to the heat), and the service impeccable.  And all this for about $65 (including tax, but not tip).  I have to say that Old Siam, while not my favorite Thai restaurant in town, is a great value.  Another consideration is it location, just off Union Square/Hallidie Plaza behind the Hilton and Parc 55 hotels.  I'll definitely go back when I'm in the neighborhood for a show or shopping.
author: George W.

description: Super tasty fried rice, yummy tom yum shrimp soup. Good prices, but not a steal. No longer a hole in the wall, actually has a sparse yet comfy decor.
author: Sarah T.

description: I got the lunch special: 1 appetizer, 1 main dish, fried rice, side of pad thai. It was a good deal at $9 and something, food was okay. I got egg rolls for my appetizer and beef green curry for my main. I asked for spicy, it definitely wasn't, but fortunately they have really good condiment trays with chile powder, chile sauce, ground peanuts, and picked chiles. Not horrible, but you can definitely find better Thai in SF and I probably wouldn't return.
author: Lydia M.

description: Wonderful food! I wish I had gone to eat here twice while visiting SF. My all time favorite meal is Pad Thai and it was to excellent! Highly recommend this place for Thai food lovers.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
I'm surprised this place got such great reviews.  I ordered a chicken Pad Thai to go for lunch, and was given shrimp Pad Thai.  Then it took them 10 minutes to remake the order, when I finally got my chicken Pad Thai it was burnt.  The kitchen is just careless when preparing orders.

If you want Thai i'd go to Bankok Noodle as they've never screwed up my order before.  Taste is comparable.
author: J C.

description: Friendly staff, fast to-go and great food.  I ordered the vegetable spring rolls, pineapple fried rice, seafood soup and two bottles of water which totalled $29.00.  The staff was super friendly and the food came within 10 minutes like they promised.  Skip the pineapple fried rice - bland.
author: T P.

description: In my sing-song voice...."it's magically delicious!!!" (yep i'm a lucky charms fan) Anyway, the other day I cheated on Siam Thai at the Parc 55 Hotel and went across the street to try the (NEW) Old Siam Thai Restaurant for lunch. It's new, it's updated & modern, and much more cozy (minus the tv's but who cares) and I get a better view outside while eating. And on top of all that, the dishes come in huge portions are packed with sooo much flavor!
author: Anne E.

description:
I happened upon this tiny place as it was directly behind our hotel.  It's not that easy on the eyes and there is a funny pillar right in front of the entrance which kind of blocks you from going inside.  On first glance it is not very welcoming, but this is quickly overcome.  The staff is genuinely courteous and appreciative.  I really think they are glad to have you as their guest and they treat you with warmth and kindness.  The tables are formica and the chairs are cheap and not very comfortable, but I digress.  Let us discuss the menu.
My first night, I had the #100, Gang Pak.  A La Carte is the way to go as you get a generous portion and can order rice on the side.  This dish is served in a bowl and is a piping hot mix of vegetables and tofu in a basil and red curry broth.  The flavors are very delicate and the spice is perfect.  For a cold night, this dish is the way to warm your heart and soul.  And, it is very healthy if you have been eating too many rich meals.  Dinner was so good that I  had to return for lunch the next day and have the exact same dish.  My boyfriend branched out and had the #76,  roasted duck.  It was succulent and decadent.  I had to refrain from stealing too many samples from his plate.  They serve this duck on top of a bed of Chinese Broccoli and this bed of greens is a health and perfect compliment to the duck.

I had to try this place one more time for dinner and again had the vegetarian Gang Pak.  Again, it was perfect and delicious.  

Day 4 I told my boyfriend to choose the lunch place.  He knew I really wanted to eat here one more time so he indulged me a 4th time in as many days!  I had to branch out and so I ordered the #92, Gang Koor, which is prawns in red curry with pineapple tomato, bell pepper and generous amounts of basil.  Yet another winner of a meal.  Just enough spice and all the flavors were delicate and balanced.  I was so sad to leave that day and not have the Old Siam as a meal option.  I will make this place stop number one on my next visit to the city by the Bay.  I would give it 5 stars, but the humble interior holds it back.  Never mind, the humble interior adds to the experience.  I give it 5 stars for being consistently delicious.
author: Molly M.

description: The soup (tom yum) was pretty good. The service was great. The portions were excessive, and it was nice place. But I've had better, wayyyyy better. The spicy wasn't spicy, the side dishes were kind of bland, and yeah... if I was drunk, i'm sure it would've gotten a 3 star review.
author: Amber G.

description: I am a Pad See Ew lover! And I've got to say this is by far the best Pad see ew I have ever had!
author: Alejandra J.

description: We were all in the mood for Thai so we just started walking around in the city.  When we got there we all wanted spicy soup and what better place than a Thai restaurant right? Well unfortunantely not at Old Siam.  When we asked for spices and hot sauce we got the typical siracha and other condiments. Not really that hot.  The soup was really good though. I had the fish ball soup and ate it so quick, but I was dissapointed that it wasn't spicy. Nothing like spice to clear you mind. Well as we were walking out I saw their specials and looked like it was geared more towards the non spicy crowd.  I'll come here again and maybe bring my own hot sauce. haha
author: Chris G.

description: I was EXTREMELY tired and hungry and nothing sounded better than a delicious plate of pad thai. I came here because I had previously been here and was pretty happy with the service and food. But I have to say, this time the food and my thai iced tea could not have come to my table any faster. Within 1-2 minutes after ordering my food, my thai iced tea (which was a little too sweet but just needed a little bit of water) was on the table and my glass of water constantly filled by the numerous waitresses. After just a few minutes my pad thai was on my table and I began to devour my dish. I could not have been happier for the fast service and good food when all I wanted was just that.
author: Brenda C.

description:
Yes, it used to be Siam Thai Noodle, and it took over Red's and renamed it Eed's. They closed for earthquake retrofitting and remodeling and renamed the whole thing The Old Siam Thai Restaurant. The ambiance is nicer, the prices are slightly, and only slightly higher, and the restroom is now accessible. But the food and the staff are the same, good and friendly respectively.

Had the pra ram tofu. The peanut sauce, unlike most places, was not bland but rather had a nice spicy undercurrent. Very good. And they now offer brown rice (yay!).

I had ordered the ala carte, but the waitperson wisely brought me (and charged me for) the cheaper rice plate. It was plenty. The price may have gone up, but the portion sizes are the same. 

The Old Siam Thai Restarant therefore now beats it's sibling across the street both in ambiance and portion size. But the TV over the bar is gone, along with the bar itself. So if you really want the TV with your dinner, you'll have to go across the street to Siam Thai Restaurant in the Parc 55 hotel. Just be aware they usually show news channels over there, not Animal Kingdom.
author: Charles B.

description: Food was good.  I had sat-ay chicken for appetizer and it was delicious.  Fast and good service.  I definitely will come back next time.
author: Rick H.

description: I usually get the combination plate which is an excellent selection of Pad thai, fried rice and starter and a main dish - all for $10...... Great Thai food
author: Anita W.

description: Perfect place for tasty, hassle free, solo dining! Oh did I mention the value? Food is authentic thai as are the typically polite and attentive staff.
author: John O.

description: the best Thai food in the Union Square area that I've eaten at.  I've tried most of the others, and they lack one important thing that "The Old Siam" does not, TASTE.  The food here is full of flavor, making it oh-so delicious.  Since my first time eating here, I've recommended several people to eat here and they've all loved it.  Almost as good as home-cooking.
author: Richard G.

description: They'd done a nice job remodeling the space (used to be a combination of Ead's and Old Siam), and it's cheap and fast. As for the quality of the food, it has been a few weeks now and I can't remember much, meaning it was average at best.
author: Jason B.

description: Food was standard Thai fare. Service extremely poor and slow, although considering it's touristy locale, hardly a surprise. Stick with places in the mission next time.
author: Cody J.

description: Great food, friendly service. Best Thai food I have found within walking distance of Union Square. Spicy chicken noodles had lots of flavor & fresh veggies/herbs and the fresh roll (? not sure what they called it, but the non-fried roll) was excellent. This will be my go-to thai in SF!
author: T M.

description: These guys serve Thai at very reasonable prices.   They will spice up your dish if you ask for it, otherwise, they do keep the heat toned down more so for the unaccustomed pallet.  I forgot to ask for Thai hot the first night, but not the 2nd and I was rewarded with a "make you sweat" dish!   The wait staff was friendly and attentative during my visits and I never had to ask for refills on the water.   We also got a nice view of the street scene where we were seated.
author: G M.

description: i stumbled into this joint by complete accident. xmas day, after a movie, walking around downtown and willing to eat ANYTHING open we ran across old siam.  service was slow(er) but what do you expect? tourist season by union square on xmas day... we were seated in about 10 min. ordered tofu red curry and chicken pad see ew. portions were huge (even the a la carte) and the total bill for two of us was a few cents over 15$. the quality was exceptional and service was prompt. king of thai is usually my stomping grounds for good thai downtown, but ive officially been converted.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Extreammmmmly!!!!!!!! Good..... 
test good
services good
price good
I feel GOOD as it gets!

Ps. PadThai is the BEST.
author: Alan M.

description: I love this place, I had walked by it several times on my way home and always wondered if it was any good.  Finally, one night I stopped in and decided to order some takeout.  I'm so glad I did!  Not only is the food decently priced, but it is good!  My favorite dish is the Tom Kha Gai soup which has this delicious, creamy coconut broth and is flavored with lemongrass.  Love it!
author: Rachel S.

description: The prices at this place weren't bad and the atmosphere is pretty aiite too, but the food is mediocre and the service I experienced was absolutely awful. The servers would never come to our table and we practically had to waive our white napkin in the air just to get their attention. And then every time we asked for something it felt like we were troubling them. The service alone is reason for me never to eat here again.
author: Omrn B.

description: VERY IMPORTANT! PLEASE READ!: Headed over to old Siam for lunch with some colleagues. Finished up the average lunch and boxed up the remaining. Walked out the door forgetting my to go box. Crossed the road and realized I did. Went back to the restaurant and it was gone (in 2 minutes). The waitress acted like she didn't know what happened to it. I happen to look across the cashiers table and one of the waiters puts his hand (in a shift serving a few tables) into the GARBAGE BIN!!! and pulls out my box. Acting shady, puts it in another bag and hands it to me. Luckily I happen to notice this. I started questioning them about what they just did and the manager walks in and takes defense , that he wouldn't force me to take the food. Do they think their customers are bums to pull food out of the bin and hand over? And the waiter is serving food with the same hands. The manager doesn't apologize and argues along. Next stop is the Dept of Public Health.
author: Karthick S.

description: i wanted to go to the siam across the street in the hotel.. but i saw this place and wanted to try it out.. (its the same owner).. but anyways, service was extremely slow and the food is not nearly as good as it is across the street. sorry old siam but im sticking to the other one.
author: JUDY L.

description: Thai food isn't tough to get right... nor is it tough to fu*k up. The food was okay. Standard Americanized Thai fare. -1 star for strangely slow service: the restaurant wasn't busy, but it took a looong time for food. Whipping up some stuff in the wok should only take a few minutes, not 25.
author: David S.

description: This hidden treasure downtown is DELICIOUS!! I always end up here when visiting downtown for shopping, its affordable and tasty and the tom kha gai is the best I have ever tasted!!! I wish they would share the secret broth recipe :D
author: K G.

description: The $10 combo meal is a great value.  You choose an appetizer and entree' and you also get fried rice and vegetarian pad thai.  It's a plateful.  The food was tasty, served fast.  The wait staff was friendly and quick to refill our water glasses.  The interior decor was very swanky and soothing with subdued lighting and dark wood.  A great place to have a meal after the hustle and bustle of shopping and shopper traffic in nearby Union Square.
author: Mark I.

description: Great place for lunch with a colleague or a friend. The lunch special is an amazing deal. The food tastes great. I cant say the service is outstanding, but they are always friendly. It's definitely a place for locals or tourists on a budget or office workers on much a needed lunch break.
author: nightlife i.

description:
if you want good  inexpensive Thai food, this is the place to go.

get their combo  dinner menu,  one appetizer and one entrees for $9.95  and for about 2 dollar more you can get the coconut soup.

This should be enough to fill you...
author: daniel s.

description: They are super friendly here and the portions are huge. I work for a non-profit in the area and I'm constantly looking for ways to serve a good and affordable meal at meetings. I can usually serve two people per a la carte entree and everyone ends up commenting that it was a good choice. Their food isn't as greasy as some Thai restaurants in the neighborhood (ahem, King of Thai) or as expensive as others (cough, cough, Muang Thai). If I come in and my food isn't ready they always bring me a glass of water while I wait. They are fab!
author: Rene S.
